tossups.question: In a poem from this country, a woman quotes the Song of Solomon when questioned at an Arizona border checkpoint. An affair with George Barker inspired a poet from this country to write By Grand Central Station I Sat Down and Wept. A poem from this country opens, "The world is full of women who'd tell me I should be ashamed" and ends, "This is a torch song. Touch me and you'll burn." This country's Griffin Prize, which was co-founded by the author of "Helen of Troy Does Countertop Dancing," was first won by an author from this country who adapted the myth of Geryon (GER-ee-en) into Autobiography of Red. The protagonist of a novel from this country leaves the Red Center, which is led by Aunt Lydia, to live with Serena Joy and the Commander. For 10 points, name this home country of Anne Carson and the author of The Handmaid's Tale, Margaret Atwood.
tossups.formatted_answer: Canada

tossups.question: Jonathan Drury used maximum likelihood estimation to show the effect of the "matching" form of this process on trait evolution. The "lottery model" shows the tradeoff between this process and colonization. The result of this process is predicted by Tilman's R* ("R-star") rule. The Ricker model, which generalizes the Beverton-Holt model, models the "scramble" form of this process. A theory of this process was refuted by the paradox of the plankton. E.O. Wilson showed that this process causes character displacement, which can also cause intraguild predation. Gause predicted that species cannot coexist if they share the same ecological niche, called this process's "exclusion principle". It's not predation, but a form of the Lotka-Volterra equations models this process. For 10 points, name this process in which organisms fight over resources.
tossups.formatted_answer: competition [or matching competition or competition-colonization tradeoff or scramble competition or competitive exclusion principle]
tossups.answer: competition [or matching competition or competition-colonization tradeoff or scramble competition or competitive exclusion principle]

The last major one of these pieces by this man, "Lessons of the Hour," lists "three distinct periods of persecution of negroes." A frequently recreated instance of this genre by this author responds to the title question with the words "a day that reveals to him…the gross injustice and cruelty to which he is the constant victim." tossups.question: Satin is placed on examples of these things haunted by ghosts called Nang Mai. The naga Muchalinda names a type of these things because he protected the Buddha from a storm. "Nirvana" is sometimes parsed as meaning to leave a place filled with these things. Such monks as Phrakru Pitak Nanthakthun wrap orange robes around these things to ordain and protect them in Cambodia and Thailand, where a group of these things provides the popular name for Ajahn Mun's Kammatthana tradition of Theravada Buddhism. Queen Maya gave birth to Siddhartha while touching one of these things called a sal. The Diamond Throne sits near one of these things in a temple at Bodh Gaya where Mara and his three daughters attempted to impede the Buddha's meditation. tossups.question: Rather than reacting with these ions, sulfides repeatedly react with themselves to form polysulfides in a degrading "shuttle" effect. Silicon nanowires are primarily being researched for their use in intercalating these ions. When bonded to iron phosphate, this ion forms a compound that is preferred for use in cathodes over cobalt oxide, since the latter is more prone to thermal runaway. In a common illustrative plot, devices using these ions have higher volumetric and specific energy densities than Ni-Cd and Ni-MH counterparts. John Goodenough won the 2019 Nobel Prize for helping to develop those devices, whose graphite anodes are intercalated with these ions during recharging. For 10 points, a prevalent rechargeable battery is named for what lightest alkali ion?
tossups.formatted_answer: lithium ions [or Li+. or lithium ion battery]
tossups.answer: lithium ions [or Li+. or lithium ion battery]

tossups.question: After losing the Battle of Sulci (SOOL-kee), a commander in this war was crucified by his own troops. The Spartan general Xanthippus (zan-THIP-us) won a decisive victory at this war's Battle of the Bagradas River. An account of this war opens Polybius's Histories. After using a captured quinquereme (KWIN-kwuh-reem) as a model, one side of this war further sidestepped inexperience in naval warfare by deploying a spiked boarding device called a corvus at the Battles of Mylae (MAI-lai) and Cape Ecnomus. After failing to pay troops, the losing side of this war faced a mutiny led by Mathos in the Mercenary War. This war broke out after Roman troops crossed the strait of Messina to relieve the Mamertines (MAM-er-teenz) from a siege by King Hiero II of Syracuse. tossups.formatted_answer: First Punic War [prompt on Punic Wars]

tossups.question: In this play, Prophet Klump claims that a prediction he made was incorrect because his watch was made in China. In this play, the fortune-teller Esmeralda predicts that it will rain, as indicated by four lights turning on in the Armageddon Tower. The protagonist of this play is re-elected as president of the Ancient and Honorable Order of Mammals. Homer plays guitar while the Muses sing "Jingle Bells" in this play's first act. tossups.question: The Cracow Circle applied formal logic to the ideas of this thinker, whom John Haldane synthesized with analytical philosophy. This thinker distinguished God's eternal law from natural law and human law from divine law in a treatise included in this philosopher's magnum opus. Philippa Foot's trolley problem popularized this thinker's principle that an action is moral if its nature and intent are moral and the good results outweigh the bad. The Salamanca School expanded on the just price concept of this formulator of the "doctrine of double effect." This philosopher listed just purpose, proper authority, and right intention as criteria for a just war in a book whose 3,125 articles answer 614 questions with citations from such authorities as Averroes and the Church Fathers. For 10 points, name this author of the Summa Theologica.
tossups.formatted_answer: Saint Thomas Aquinas [or Thomas of Aquino; accept Doctor Angelicus, Communis, or Universalis; accept analytical Thomism; accept Cracow Circle Thomism]

tossups.question: A photograph of this person shows them hunched over a microscope perched on top of a book, examining the bacterium that causes leprosy. They're not Albert Einstein, but in another photograph this person grins and brushes their chin with their hand as Charlie Chaplin sits next to them on a couch. This person's great-nephew spent a decade taking photographs of them, including one in which they stand on a scale beside a doorway as a man in the corner of the room weighs them. Numerous photographs of this man taken for Life magazine show him walking with his arms resting on the shoulders of two younger female relatives for support. tossups.question: According to the Spaniards, the Tagalog people prayed to a deity of this domain to make them rich. A Korean folktale tells how a boy escapes from a tiger by climbing a rope and becoming a god of this domain. Some traditions hold that a god of this domain was born from a perfectly clear mirror held in his father's hand. That god of this domain was more commonly said to be born from the right eye of Izanagi while he was cleansing himself. The "Chinese Sisyphus", Wu Gang, endlessly cuts down a tree in this place. tossups.question: Following a solo trumpet "bugle call," this instrument crescendos for two measures before the rest of the orchestra rejoins in the coda to the second movement of the "Military"symphony. The solo for this instrument in the "Agnus Dei" of the Mass in Time of War lends the mass an alternate nickname. In the first movement of the "Surprise" symphony, Haydn provided three measures for this instrument to retune. The opening passage for this instrument nicknames the penultimate London symphony, while its use in producing the fortissimo chord in the "Surprise" symphony lends that work its German nickname. tossups.question: In an incompressible plane flow with this property, the wave speed corresponding to an instability is constrained by Howard's semicircle theorem. Assuming that this property holds often means that the no-slip condition cannot be applied, due to reduction in order. This property is assumed to hold for a fluid outside the boundary layer. When this property holds for an adiabatic fluid, the Laplacian term vanishes from the Navier-Stokes equations, which thus reduce to the Euler (OIL-er) equations. A cylinder moving in a fluid with this theoretical property experiences no drag in d'Alembert's (DAH-lom-bear's) paradox. Real materials with this fluid property form Rollin (ROW-lan) films as they "crawl out" of their containers, and include helium-4 below its lambda point. tossups.formatted_answer: zero viscosity [or inviscid; accept anything indicating that viscosity is zero or that the fluid is not viscous; or superfluidity before "superfluids" is read]
tossups.answer: zero viscosity [or inviscid; accept anything indicating that viscosity is zero or that the fluid is not viscous; or superfluidity before "superfluids" is read]

tossups.question: This author, the paradigmatic sufferer of Geschwind syndrome, nicknames the prerequisite condition for it commonly called TLE. This author may have experienced symptoms of Stendhal syndrome when viewing Holbein's Dead Christ, like one of this author's protagonists. bonuses.leadin: Along with infinite regress and the dogmatic argument, this fallacy comprises the Agrippan trilemma. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this fallacy, in which the argument's premises assume its conclusion. This fallacy named for a shape is closely related to the idea of "begging the question".

The Agrippan trilemma is named after a member of this school of thought, who formulated five modes that establish the necessity of epoché (eh-poh-KAY). Aenesidemus (EE-ness-ih-DEE-muss) proposed ten modes within this ancient school of thought.
This Greek philosopher of the second century CE attributed the five modes of Agrippa "to the more recent skeptics" in his work Outlines of Pyrrhonism.
answers: circular reasoning [or circular logic; accept circulus in probando; prompt on begging the question]
formatted_answers: circular reasoning [or circular logic; accept circulus in probando; prompt on begging the question]

bonuses.leadin: This dancer is credited with inventing the modern pointe (pwant) shoe. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Russian ballerina who popularized the "Mexican Hat Dance" with a version she performed in pointe shoes. This rival of Tamara Karsavina premiered Michel Fokine (foh-KEEN)'s The Dying Swan.

Pavlova and Karsavina both danced for the modern Mariinsky Ballet and for this company founded in Paris by Sergei Diaghilev. Fokine left this company when Diaghilev instead had Nijinsky choreograph Afternoon of a Faun.

This dancer, who choreographed "Radha-Krishna" as a duet with Pavlova, is credited as the father of modern Indian dance. His brother convinced Maihar's Maharaja to let Allaudin Khan play sarod for their company.

bonuses.leadin: Mercenaries nicknamed for these body parts first developed the "Highland charge" while working for Irish armies in the 17th century. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these body parts. The unusually tall "Hammer of the Scots" Edward I was nicknamed for having "long" instances of these things.

Redshanks were seasonal alternatives to these axe-carrying mercenaries whose name translates to "foreign Gaels." First employed after the Norman invasion of Ireland, these mercenaries were central to Irish warfare until the 16th century.

Prior to the Norman Invasion, these clan-wide conflicts dominated Irish warfare as a means to increase wealth before the development of currency. One of these conflicts at Cooley is depicted in the Táin Bó Cúailnge (TINE boh COOLN-yeh) as part of a namesake genre of epics.
answers: shanks [or shins; or legs; or redshanks; or Edward Longshanks]
formatted_answers: shanks [or shins; or legs; or redshanks; or Edward Longshanks]

bonuses.leadin: According to Trevor Horn, this author's story in which a mute boy vacuums sounds in a world of "ultrasonic music" inspired the song "Video Killed the Radio Star." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this British author of "The Sound-Sweep" and the novel Crash, whose other novels inspired Joy Division's "Atrocity Exhibition" and the name of the band Empire of the Sun.

William Gibson claimed that Ballard was a precursor to this genre. Gibson's novel Neuromancer was central to the development of this genre, which combines "lowlife and high tech" according to Brian Sterling.

Under the alias k-punk, "cybernetic culture" theorist Mark Fisher wrote an essay likening callout culture to the castles of these characters. Characters of this type include Sheridan Le Fanu's Carmilla and John Polidori's Lord Ruthven.

bonuses.leadin: The importance of these proteins to a plant's roots can be demonstrated by blocking them with mercury chloride. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these proteins discovered by Peter Agre ("AG-ray"). Vasopressin increases the number of these proteins in the collecting duct.
Aquaporins mostly appear in these general structures, which consist of phospholipid bilayers. In plant cells, the cell wall surrounds the "plasma" one of these structures.
Aquaporins also play an important role in this membrane, which surround the vacuole of a plant cell.

The longue durée approach was used by the Annales school to analyze this field of study. Herodotus was considered the "father" of this study of the past.

bonuses.leadin: The Bibliotheca of Pseudo-Apollodorus claims that this woman cursed her husband to ejaculate scorpions and snakes that killed his mistresses. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this woman. This woman hid inside a structure created by Daedalus in order to get pregnant with Asterius.
This king, Pasiphaё's husband, ordered Daedalus to construct a labyrinth to house the half-human half-bull Asterius.
This woman cured Minos after he was cursed by Pasiphaё. As a result, Minos gifted this wife of Cephalus with an infallible javelin and a dog who would always be able to hunt its prey called Laelaps.

bonuses.leadin: A character in this play tells a White housing representative, "We will try to be good neighbors. And that's all we got to say about that." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Lorraine Hansberry play about the Younger family's struggles to move into a White Chicago neighborhood.

The Korean War veteran Kenneth commits suicide outside the central house of this 2010 play, written as a spin-off of A Raisin in the Sun. In the first act of this play, the White couple Bev and Russ argue about integrating their neighborhood.

This character, who is married to the deaf Betsy, announces to Bev and Russ that a Black family is moving into Clybourne Park. In A Raisin in the Sun, this White representative approaches Walter about buying out their house to supposedly ease racial tensions.

bonuses.leadin: The Laplacian (luh-PLASS-ee-un) is equal to the trace of this matrix. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this square matrix, which consists of the second-order partial derivatives of a scalar function or field.

Hessians are used in the second partial derivative test to determine the nature of these points, at which the gradient is zero. For example, if the Hessian is positive definite at one of these points, then that point must be a local minimum.
This quantity is equal to the determinant of the Hessian at a given point on a surface. The Theorema Egregium states that this quantity is invariant under local isometry.
answers: Gaussian curvature [or Gauss curvature; prompt on curvature or principal curvature; prompt on K]
formatted_answers: Gaussian curvature [or Gauss curvature; prompt on curvature or principal curvature; prompt on K]

bonuses.leadin: According to Robert Greenberg, this composition's opening threnody represents attack helicopters. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this work subtitled "Thirteen Images from the Dark Land" and dated "Friday the Thirteenth." Its "Night of the Electric Insects" plays as welts spell out "Help me" on Regan's body in The Exorcist.
George Crumb's Black Angels inspired David Harrington to found a chamber ensemble of this type, and quotes a Schubert piece for this ensemble titled for his lied "Death and the Maiden."

Harrington's Kronos Quartet led this composer to return to notated music. Meher Baba co-names a tribute by Pete Townshend with a modal ostinato opening inspired by this minimalist, who wrote A Rainbow in Curved Air and In C.
answers: Terry Riley (The second line refers to The Who's "Baba O'Riley")
formatted_answers: Terry Riley (The second line refers to The Who's "Baba O'Riley")

bonuses.leadin: You are a faqih in Turkey. Answer the following about your practice of Islamic jurisprudence, for 10 points each:
parts: Your fatwas draw from the Quran and the life and practice of Muhammad, as suggested by your membership in this largest Muslim denomination. Hence, you may refer to Shiites as Alevier.

When consulted on the rules of this "partial" form of ritual ablution, contrasted with the more rigorous ghusl, you declare that its four obligatory components are washing the face, arms, head, and feet.

You are a member of this largest madhhab (ma--THAHB), which emphasizes reason and the use of istihsan. This school of jurisprudence is also popular in India and Central Asia, unlike the competing Hanbali, Maliki, and Shafi'i schools.
answers: Hanafi school [or Hanafi madhhab; or Hanafi fiqh; prompt on Ahl al-Ra'y]
formatted_answers: Hanafi school [or Hanafi madhhab; or Hanafi fiqh; prompt on Ahl al-Ra'y]

bonuses.leadin: Before serving as president of this country, a Methodist minister wrote a book of Black liberation theology titled The Gospel According to the Ghetto, which contains a prayer that begins "Our Father who art in the Ghetto." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this present-day country, whose interim government was led by a different Methodist bishop until elections specified by the Lancaster House Agreement.
Most of this majority ethnic group of Zimbabwe are Christian but retain elements of an indigenous religion centered on the creator Mwari.

This Anglican archbishop was once mistaken for Zimbabwe's Bishop Abel Muzorewa on a plane. This founder of Ubuntu theology chaired the Truth and Reconciliation Commission established in South Africa in 1995.
answers: Zimbabwe [Republic of Zimbabwe; do not accept "Southern Rhodesia"; do not accept "Rhodesia"; do not accept "Zimbabwe Rhodesia"] [the former minister was Canaan Banana; the latter bishop is Abel Muzorewa]
formatted_answers: Zimbabwe [Republic of Zimbabwe; do not accept "Southern Rhodesia"; do not accept "Rhodesia"; do not accept "Zimbabwe Rhodesia"] [the former minister was Canaan Banana; the latter bishop is Abel Muzorewa]

bonuses.leadin: Vyacheslav Kyrylenko ("vee-ATCH-eh-slav ki-ri-LEN-koh") controversially forbade the wheelchair-bound 18-year-old Yuliya Samoylova ("YOO-lee-ya sah-moy-LOH-va") from entering his country to take part in this event in 2017. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this event. Heavy political overtones probably helped Kalush Orchestra win this event in May 2022.
Since the invasion of Crimea in 2014, Eurovision has often been a stage for political stunts between Russia and this other country, which Russia launched a full-scale invasion of in 2022.

Ukraine's original 2022 entrant was an artist with this first name who was withdrawn due to illegal entry into Russian-occupied Crimea in 2015. Switzerland refuses to deport a former gymnast and long-term mistress of Vladimir Putin with this first name.

bonuses.leadin: A book in this genre illustrates the concept of impermanence by describing various natural disasters. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this genre consisting of loosely connected ideas and essays, whose name translates as "follow the brush." The 11th-century book An Account of My Hut is in this genre.
This zuihitsu book by Sei Shōnagon is a collection of anecdotes and essays about court life in Heian-era Japan.
Sei Shōnagon often feuded with this other writer, who described interactions with Shōnagon in her namesake diary. This author also wrote The Tale of Genji.

bonuses.leadin: These substances have a compressibility factor of one. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these substances whose namesake law states PV = nRT ["P-V equals N-R-T"].
A monatomic ideal gas is often considered to have a value of 5/3 for this quantity, which is 7/5 for a diatomic ideal gas.

The adiabatic index of an ideal gas can be calculated as one plus two over the number of these entities. The number of these parameters equals the number of chemical components, minus the number of phases, plus two, according to a rule named for Gibbs.
answers: adiabatic index [or adiabatic exponent; or heat capacity ratio; or ratio of heat capacities; or specific heat ratio; or ratio of specific heats; or Laplace's coefficient; prompt on gamma]
formatted_answers: adiabatic index [or adiabatic exponent; or heat capacity ratio; or ratio of heat capacities; or specific heat ratio; or ratio of specific heats; or Laplace's coefficient; prompt on gamma]

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the "ease of doing business," for 10 points each:
parts: This organization's Ease of Doing Business report was cancelled in 2021 after an audit showed its leaders had pressured economists to falsify the data. This organization was founded to loan money to the developing world alongside the IMF.

The World Bank's Ease of Doing Business report was partly inspired by an experiment undertaken by this economist, who found that it took 289 days to start a business in his country. This economist advocated for property rights in The Other Path.

de Soto discussed his experiment in a book titled for "the Mystery of" this economic concept. de Soto criticized a 2013 book by a French economist partly titled for this concept, which discusses the inequality "r is greater than g."
answers: capital [or The Mystery of Capital or Capital in the Twenty-First Century or El misterio del capital or Le Capital au XXIe siècle]
formatted_answers: capital [or The Mystery of Capital or Capital in the Twenty-First Century or El misterio del capital or Le Capital au XXIe siècle]

bonuses.leadin: In a poem that Richmond Lattimore translated as this city's "Creed," the speaker "would not say anything for a man nor take account of him" for such accolades as the ability to "outrun Boreas." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this home city of Tyrtaeus. An epigram by Simonides asks, "Stranger, go tell" this city's inhabitants that "we lie here, obedient to their words."

Alcman, whose partheneia praise the athletic women of Sparta, was the earliest member of this many canonical Greek lyric poets. Sappho was sometimes referred to by a name indicating her addition to this traditional number of muses.
"Alcmanian verse" is a tetrameter largely made up of these metrical feet, as in Tyrtaeus's elegiac couplets. This metrical foot names the type of hexameter common to Greek and Latin epics.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about Tanjore painting, for 10 points each:
parts: Tanjore paintings begin with the application of a limestone-based gesso to this material onto which paint, precious stones, and gold leaf were applied. Ukiyo-e prints began as carvings on blocks of this material.

Tanjore paintings depart from traditional Indian paintings by their inclusion of these objects. American Empire style contrasts with acanthus leaf-heavy European designs for these objects, a design for a massive one of which in Dubai was created by Fernando Donis.

The "artist-saint" C. Kondiah Raju created taught his students to create Tanjore paintings for these objects. Rings emanate from the sun god Tonatiuh in the center of a circular, stone sculpture of one of these objects that was buried under the Zócalo.
answers: wood [or bark; or wooden boards; or maram; or palagai padam; or woodblocks; or specific types of wood such as jackfruit wood]
frame [or word forms like framing or being framed; or a picture frame; or the Dubai Frame]
calendar [or accept the Aztec Calendar; prompt on the Sun Stone with "What was its purpose?"]
formatted_answers: wood [or bark; or wooden boards; or maram; or palagai padam; or woodblocks; or specific types of wood such as jackfruit wood]
frame [or word forms like framing or being framed; or a picture frame; or the Dubai Frame]
calendar [or accept the Aztec Calendar; prompt on the Sun Stone with "What was its purpose?"]

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following about orange juice in American history.
parts: In this city, Black teenager Latasha Harlins was shot and killed by Soon Ja Du after being falsely suspected of stealing a bottle of orange juice. That event and the and the acquittal of four policemen for beating Rodney King led to riots in this California city in 1992.
Paul Douglas brought a pitcher of orange juice to the person who spoke for 24 hours and 18 minutes during this record-setting 1957 event.

Many gay rights groups boycotted Florida orange juice after this singer and spokeswoman for the Florida Citrus Commission campaigned to repeal an ordinance in Miami-Dade County that prohibited discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.
answers: Strom Thurmond's filibuster of the Civil Rights Act of 1957 [prompt on filibuster; accept James Strom Thurmond Sr. in place of "Strom Thurmond"]
formatted_answers: Strom Thurmond's filibuster of the Civil Rights Act of 1957 [prompt on filibuster; accept James Strom Thurmond Sr. in place of "Strom Thurmond"]

bonuses.leadin: The free energy is Taylor expanded in powers of the order parameter in Landau's ("LAND-ow's") theory of the continuous type of these phenomena. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these phenomena, whose discontinuous type is described by the Clausius-Clapeyron ("CLOW-zee-uss-clap-AY-ron") relation.

Remarkably, many continuous phase transitions have common values for "universal" exponents named for this adjective. This adjective names a "point" on a phase diagram beyond which gas and liquid states cannot be distinguished.
Kenneth Wilson's work on universality in phase transitions focused on groups named for this technique, which Richard Feynman infamously described as "hocus-pocus."
answers: renormalization [accept word forms; or renormalization group flow; do not accept or prompt on "normalization"]
formatted_answers: renormalization [accept word forms; or renormalization group flow; do not accept or prompt on "normalization"]

bonuses.leadin: A poem titled for this action states that "I was stamped out like a Plymouth fender into this world" and concludes that a "story ends with me still" performing this action. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this action. The last poem in a collection titled for this "awful" action describes the speaker getting a royal flush in poker after arriving at "the island called God."
This poet wrote An Awful Rowing Toward God. This author of "Wanting to Die" proclaimed, "I have gone out, a possessed witch" to open the poem "Her Kind," collected in To Bedlam and Part Way Back.
Like Sharon Olds and Robert Lowell, Sexton was a member of this movement of the 1950s and 1960s, whose members wrote poetry focused on individual experience and personal trauma.
answers: rowing [or An Awful Rowing Toward God; or "The Rowing Endeth"]
formatted_answers: rowing [or An Awful Rowing Toward God; or "The Rowing Endeth"]
